slides.title: Origins of the Hot Dog
content: The hot dog has a rich history that dates back centuries.
Its origins can be traced to ancient cultures such as the Babylonians, who made sausages from minced meat.
The modern hot dog as we know it today, however, has its roots in Germany.
German immigrants brought their tradition of sausages to the United States in the 19th century.
slides.speaker_notes: In this slide, we will explore the origins of the hot dog and its connection to ancient cultures and Germany. We will discuss the role of German immigrants in introducing sausages to the United States.

slides.title: The Birth of the Hot Dog in America
content: In the late 19th century, German immigrants began selling sausages on the streets of major American cities.
These sausages were typically served in a bun, making them easy to eat on the go.
The term 'hot dog' is believed to have originated in the early 20th century, with various theories about its exact source.
One popular theory is that the term was coined by a cartoonist who couldn't spell 'dachshund', a type of sausage commonly used in hot dogs.
slides.speaker_notes: This slide will focus on the introduction of hot dogs in America by German immigrants. We will discuss the evolution of serving sausages in a bun and the origins of the term 'hot dog'.

slides.title: Hot Dogs and Baseball
content: Hot dogs became closely associated with baseball games in the early 20th century.
Vendors started selling hot dogs at baseball stadiums, and they quickly became a popular snack among spectators.
The connection between hot dogs and baseball has endured to this day, with hot dogs being a staple at baseball games across the United States.
In fact, the National Hot Dog and Sausage Council estimates that baseball fans consume over 20 million hot dogs at Major League Baseball games each season.
slides.speaker_notes: This slide will explore the association between hot dogs and baseball. We will discuss the tradition of selling hot dogs at baseball stadiums and the enduring popularity of hot dogs among baseball fans.

slides.title: Hot Dogs Around the World
content: Hot dogs have become a beloved food around the world, with each country putting its own unique twist on the classic recipe.
In Mexico, for example, hot dogs are often topped with a variety of condiments including avocado, salsa, and jalapenos.
In Japan, 'octo-dogs' are popular, which are hot dogs shaped like octopuses.
In Sweden, 'tunnbrödsrulle' is a popular street food that combines a hot dog with mashed potatoes, shrimp salad, and other toppings.
